Can you tell me about the governor in an engine?

Of course! The governor in an engine is a device used to maintain the engine speed of an internal combustion engine within certain limits to prevent damage and wear. It achieves this by regulating the amount of fuel or working fluid supplied to the engine.
How does it work?

The governor works by sensing changes in the load requirements for the engine. If the engine begins to speed up uncontrolled (like in case of a reduction in load), the governor reduces the fuel input to the engine and thus slows the speed. Similarly, if the load increases (and the engine threatens to slow down), the governor increases the fuel input thus keeping the speed constant. It's an essential component that controls and maintains the operating speed of an engine irrespective of the variations in load.
